## GAD-7 vs MINI

GAD-7 vs MINI In the field of psychology and social sciences, comparing instruments like the Generalised Anxiety Disorder Assessment (GAD-7) and the MINI-International Neuropsychiatric Interview (MINI) are major necessities. The GAD-7, a seven-item instrument, measures the severity of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), while the MINI assesses various psychiatric disorders. However, the process of comparing and harmonizing such instruments can be challenging, time-consuming, and subjective. Therefore, software like Harmony is integral in the 'GAD-7 vs MINI' process to streamline the process of harmonization. The key benefit of using Harmony in the 'GAD-7 vs MINI' comparison is that Harmony has powerful machine-learning algorithms to perform complex tasks like harmonization. It uses natural language processing and generative AI models to match items in different questionnaires. Even more beneficial, Harmony can handle instruments written in different languages. Therefore, examining 'GAD-7 vs MINI' potential similarities and differences is made easy even when presented in various languages. "Meticulous research and constant validation through subsequent studies are the backbones of progressive psychological findings. That's where instruments like GAD-7 and MINI come into play. By using Harmony, researchers can efficiently compare 'GAD-7 vs MINI', providing a comprehensive understanding of these instruments and their applications. The convenience of dropping your PDFs directly into the web application makes Harmony not only a scientifically valuable tool but also a user-friendly resource for psychologists and researchers alike.

## Compare the items in GAD-7 English and MINI

## Questions in GAD-7

|   No. | GAD-7 English                                                                                                                                      |
|------:|:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|     1 | Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge                                                                                                               |
|     2 | Not being able to stop or control worrying                                                                                                         |
|     3 | Worrying too much about different things                                                                                                           |
|     4 | Trouble relaxing                                                                                                                                   |
|     5 | Being so restless that it is hard to sit still                                                                                                     |
|     6 | Becoming easily annoyed or irritable                                                                                                               |
|     7 | Feeling afraid, as if something awful might happen                                                                                                 |
|     8 | If you checked any problems, how difficult have they made it for you to do your work, take care of things at home, or get along with other people? |
